Award.AwardTitle: Effect of Light and Temperature Cycles and Climate Change on Adaptation in Lizards
Award.AbstractNarration:
Barry Sinervo IOS 1022031

Effect of Light and Temperature Cycles and Climate Change on Adaptation in Lizards

Recent climate changes in maximum daily temperatures during spring and summer in many parts of the world appear to be driving local population extinctions of many lizard species. Field studies of key reproductive parameters such as breeding time will be conducted on the side-blotched lizard, a species with detailed information on genetics of lay date in nature. Breeding time is expected to change rapidly under the observed 2Â°C shift in maximum daily spring temperatures observed during the past two decades in California. The researchers expect to find strong natural selection on breeding time. In laboratory experiments, the researchers will study climate-warming effects on "plastic changes" in breeding time to determine physiological limits of acclimation to climate warming. For example, climate warming is expected to induce earlier breeding but this plastic shift in lay date, due to milder winters, may paradoxically generate strong selection for later lay dates because the optimal period for summer juvenile growth has not changed. Finally, a theoretical model that has been used to accurately predict worldwide extinctions of lizards will be used to predict locations of ongoing population extinctions of side-blotch lizards across the US and Mexico. The predictions will be verified with ground-truth surveys and measurements of microclimate. This study will supply critical information on how species adapt to rapid climate change and if adaptation is not possible, it will estimate extinction likelihood. Lizard species are a valuable model because of well-developed methods for studying natural selection, genetics and thermal physiology. Understanding climate effects on ecology of single species (e.g., demography, reproduction) is a first step in understanding climate impacts on ecosystem functioning. These issues are vital for predicting climate impacts on any ecosystem functioning, human agricultural systems included.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We studied natural selection on traits related to physiology (thermal preference) and life history (clutch size, egg size, lay date) due to ongoing climate change over the past 28 years in the common side-blotched lizard. We began the studies on the side-blotched lizard in 1986, when we first measured lay date across the species range. We have also been following a focal population at Los Banos, CA since 1989, when we initiated a field pedigree study. We have observed dramatic changes in the lay date due to warming temperatures in the winter months (Dec, Jan, Feb), which allows the lizards to breed approximately 2 weeks earlier than during the late 1980s, at the focal population as well as across the range in 10 populations distributed from Mexico to Washinton State. 

We used the field pedigree to study evolved changes in lay date and have observed dramatic natural selection for earlier lay date. In addition, we measured the effects of warming temperatures on growth of the side-blotched lizard and the accelaration in time to maturity in the laboratory. We find that the earlier lay date is due ot a combination of evolved changes in laydate and the plastic effects of warming temperatures on growth rate, which allows earlier maturation. 

We also measured the heretability in body temperature regulation and find that the inheritance of body temperature regulation of progeny is due to a complex interaction that arises from the thermal preference of the mother during the development of eggs in the oviduct and a major genetic locus that governs life history traits. 

We also developed an entirely new class of species distribution modeling methods, premised on physiology, which we have since applied to the lizards of the world, and to tortoises of the world. We find that many populations of reptiles are undergoing a process of local population extinctions due to physiological limits being exceeded as climate has warmed dramatically since 1975. We have since developed new protocols for measuring the physiological consequences of warming temperatures and drought on reptiles and amphibians. In addition we have begun developing models of the impacts of disease processes on reptiles and amphibians, which are triggered by the stresses of climate warming and drought.

We have developed a five day workshop where we teach other researchers around the world in the new methods of species distribution modeling such that others can study the impacts of a climate change on biodiversity of reptiles and amphibians. We have trained over 100 researchers in these new methods.
